channel.title: NPR Topics: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: A researcher's effort to make edible cotton seeds
item.description: Edible cotton seeds could revolutionize the cotton industry. That's the goal of one researcher who says the seeds would be an inexpensive protein source that could help feed millions of people.
item.content:encoded: Edible cotton seeds could revolutionize the cotton industry. That's the goal of  one researcher who says the seeds would be an inexpensive protein source that could help feed millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Michael Marks

item.title: An ape, a tea party — and the ability to imagine
item.description: The ability to imagine — to play pretend — has long been thought to be unique to humans. A new study suggests one of our closest living relatives can do it too.
item.content:encoded: The ability to imagine — to play pretend — has long been thought to be unique to humans. A new study suggests one of our closest living relatives can do it too.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: This complex brain network may explain many of Parkinson's stranger symptoms
item.description: Parkinson's disease appears to disrupt a brain network involved in everything from movement to memory.
item.content:encoded:
'/>

Parkinson's disease appears to disrupt a brain network involved in everything from movement to memory.

(Image credit: Sara Moser)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: US scientists adapt after the Trump administration's funding blows
item.description: Scientists say the Trump administration's policies have led to major changes and uncertainty about scientific efforts and accomplishments.
item.content:encoded: Scientists say the Trump administration's policies have led to major changes and uncertainty about scientific efforts and accomplishments.
item.dc:creator: Kate Grumke

item.title: The physics of the spiral pass have long been a mystery. Not anymore
item.description: The physics of the spiral pass have baffled physicists and football fans for decades.
item.content:encoded: The physics of the spiral pass have baffled physicists and football fans for decades.
item.dc:creator: Kai McNamee

item.title: The seismometers at the end of the earth have names
item.description: Scientists have placed two seismometers 8000 feet below the ice cap at the South Pole to measure earthquakes and support tsunami alerts.
item.content:encoded: Scientists have placed two seismometers 8000 feet below the ice cap at the South Pole to measure earthquakes and support tsunami alerts.
item.dc:creator: Kai McNamee

item.title: What we know about the massive sewage leak in the Potomac River
item.description: A collapsed sewer line, about 8 miles from the White House, pumped 368 Olympic-sized swimming pools worth of wastewater into the Potomac. Repairs could take longer than previously expected.
item.content:encoded:
A collapsed sewer line, about 8 miles from the White House, pumped 368 Olympic-sized swimming pools worth of wastewater into the Potomac. Repairs could take longer than previously expected.

(Image credit: Cliff Owen)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: Researchers say when it comes to our attention spans, we are at war
item.description: NPR's Scott Simon speaks to writer Matt Klein about how to win back our attention in an age of infinite information.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Simon speaks to writer Matt Klein about how to win back our attention in an age of infinite information.
item.dc:creator: Hadeel Al-Shalchi

item.title: Can't solve a puzzle? Sleep on it, a new study suggests
item.description: NPR's Short Wave talks about babies' perceptions of rhythm, how sleep may help us solve puzzles and why snakes may be able to fast so long.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Short Wave talks about babies' perceptions of rhythm, how sleep may help us solve puzzles and why snakes may be able to fast so long.
item.dc:creator: Regina G. Barber

item.title: The Winter Olympics in Italy were meant to be sustainable. Are they?
item.description: Italy's Winter Olympics promised sustainability. But in Cortina, environmentalists warn the Games could scar these mountains for decades.
item.content:encoded:
Italy's Winter Olympics promised sustainability. But in Cortina, environmentalists warn the Games could scar these mountains for decades.

(Image credit: Valerio Muscella for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock
